results.description: Standard medical necessity denial with full clinical context

data.plain_english_explanation: Anthem denied the lumbar spine MRI because they determined it wasn't medically necessary under their coverage guidelines. Even though your doctor documented 8 weeks of conservative treatment for chronic low back pain, the insurer's criteria for approving this imaging study were not met.
likely_root_causes: Anthem's medical policy may require longer conservative treatment before authorizing MRI imaging.
Clinical documentation may not have demonstrated specific red flag symptoms justifying advanced imaging.
Prior authorization was not obtained before the MRI was performed.
Documentation may not show failed conservative therapies like physical therapy or medication trials.
missing_information_needed: Anthem's specific medical necessity policy for lumbar MRI and required conservative treatment duration.
Whether prior authorization was required and if it was requested before service.
Complete clinical notes showing symptom severity, neurological findings, and treatment response.
Anthem's criteria for red flag symptoms that would justify earlier imaging.
recommended_next_steps: Request Anthem's medical policy for lumbar spine MRI to identify specific coverage criteria.
Obtain detailed letter from ordering physician explaining why MRI was medically necessary now.
Gather all documentation of conservative treatments, medications, and patient's lack of improvement.
File a formal appeal within Anthem's deadline, including all clinical records and policy justification.
appeal_checklist: Physician letter of medical necessity specifically addressing Anthem's policy criteria for lumbar MRI.
Complete treatment timeline showing 8+ weeks conservative care and clinical response documentation.
Clinical notes documenting pain severity, functional limitations, and any neurological symptoms present.
Copy of Anthem's medical policy with highlighted sections showing how case meets criteria.
risk_warnings: CO group code means provider cannot bill patient; appeal is required to recover payment.
Appeal deadlines are typically 180 days but verify Anthem's specific timeframe immediately.
If appeal fails, patient is not responsible for payment under contractual obligation rules.

results.description: Prior auth not obtained before outpatient MRI

data.plain_english_explanation: UnitedHealthcare denied this MRI claim because the radiology center did not get approval before performing the scan. The insurance requires prior authorization for outpatient MRIs. Since this is a contractual requirement, the provider cannot bill you for the denied amount.
likely_root_causes: Radiology center failed to obtain prior authorization before the MRI scan
Authorization request may have been submitted but not approved in time
Provider may have incorrect or missing authorization number on file
Service may require specific authorization type that was not obtained
missing_information_needed: Was any authorization request submitted to UnitedHealthcare before the service date
Does the provider have an authorization number that was not included on claim
What is UnitedHealthcare's specific prior authorization policy for CPT 73721 MRIs
Is retroactive authorization available for this service and diagnosis
recommended_next_steps: Contact radiology center to confirm whether authorization was requested before January 20, 2026
Ask provider to check if retroactive authorization can be requested from UnitedHealthcare
Request provider resubmit claim with correct authorization number if one exists
Verify with UnitedHealthcare policy whether knee MRI for meniscus tear requires prior auth
appeal_checklist: Obtain documentation showing authorization was requested or approved before service date
Gather clinical notes showing medical necessity for MRI of suspected meniscus tear
Collect UnitedHealthcare contract terms regarding prior authorization requirements for outpatient imaging
Include any correspondence between provider and UnitedHealthcare about authorization status
risk_warnings: Provider cannot bill you for this denied amount due to contractual obligation
Retroactive authorization may not be available depending on UnitedHealthcare policy and timing
Appeal must be filed within UnitedHealthcare's deadline, verify timeframe immediately

results.description: Member not eligible on date of service - coverage gap

data.plain_english_explanation: Cigna denied this annual wellness exam claim because their records show your coverage ended before the February 3, 2026 visit. The provider cannot bill you for this under contract rules. This is likely an eligibility verification error, not a medical necessity issue.
likely_root_causes: Coverage termination date in Cigna's system predates the service date
Eligibility verification at check-in used outdated or incorrect insurance information
COBRA continuation or reinstatement not reflected in payer's real-time eligibility system
Administrative lag between premium payment and system update of active coverage status
missing_information_needed: Exact coverage termination date from Cigna's eligibility response or member portal
Proof of active coverage on February 3, 2026 (ID card, premium receipts, HR letter)
COBRA election notice or reinstatement confirmation if applicable
Real-time eligibility check result from date of service showing active or terminated status
recommended_next_steps: Contact Cigna member services immediately to confirm coverage status on February 3, 2026
Request corrected eligibility dates if coverage was active; obtain written confirmation from Cigna
If COBRA or reinstatement applies, submit election forms and payment proof with appeal
Provider should resubmit claim with corrected eligibility documentation once Cigna confirms active coverage
appeal_checklist: Copy of insurance card showing coverage effective date and member ID number
Premium payment receipts or payroll deduction records covering the service date period
HR letter or COBRA election notice confirming active coverage on February 3, 2026
Cigna's corrected eligibility confirmation letter or portal screenshot showing active status
risk_warnings: If coverage truly terminated before service, you may owe full charges for the visit
Appeal deadlines vary; verify Cigna's timeframe to avoid forfeiting your right to dispute
Provider may send bill to collections if eligibility issue remains unresolved beyond billing cycle

results.description: Claim filed past payer timely filing deadline

data.plain_english_explanation: Aetna denied this routine blood panel claim because the lab submitted it 14 months after the service date, exceeding the filing deadline. CO-29 means this is a contract rule, so the provider cannot bill you. The lab missed the deadline to submit the claim on time.
likely_root_causes: Lab delayed claim submission by over a year after the blood draw.
Lab may have had billing system issues or administrative backlog.
Provider did not track timely filing deadlines for this payer.
missing_information_needed: Aetna's specific timely filing limit in the provider contract.
Whether any prior claim submission attempts were made and rejected.
Documentation of any extenuating circumstances that delayed filing.
recommended_next_steps: Provider should review Aetna contract for exact timely filing deadline.
Check if claim was submitted earlier but rejected; gather proof of prior submission.
If no valid reason for delay, provider must write off balance per contract.
Provider should not bill patient due to CO group code contractual obligation.
appeal_checklist: Proof of timely submission if claim was filed within deadline but processed late.
Electronic submission confirmation or certified mail receipt showing earlier filing date.
Documentation of payer system errors or delays that prevented timely filing.
Evidence of extenuating circumstances like natural disaster or payer processing issues.
risk_warnings: Appeal unlikely to succeed if no proof of timely filing exists.
Provider cannot balance bill patient due to contractual obligation.
Future claims must be filed within payer deadline to avoid denial.

results.description: COB denial - other insurance should be primary

data.plain_english_explanation: Blue Cross Blue Shield denied this claim because the patient has two insurance plans. The spouse's employer plan is primary and should pay first. BCBS is secondary and won't pay until the primary insurer processes the claim. The office visit for upper respiratory infection was billed to the wrong insurance first.
likely_root_causes: Claim submitted to secondary payer (BCBS) before primary payer (spouse's employer plan) processed it.
Coordination of benefits information may not have been updated in BCBS system.
Primary insurance EOB was not attached when submitting to BCBS as secondary payer.
Provider may not have verified which insurance is primary before billing.
missing_information_needed: Name and policy number of spouse's primary employer insurance plan.
Copy of primary insurance card showing effective dates and coverage details.
Confirmation whether claim was already submitted to primary payer and outcome.
Primary payer's EOB showing payment or denial if claim was already processed.
recommended_next_steps: Contact spouse's employer insurance to verify it is primary and submit claim there first.
Once primary payer processes claim, obtain detailed EOB showing payment and patient responsibility.
Resubmit claim to BCBS with primary payer's EOB attached as secondary claim.
Update coordination of benefits information with BCBS to prevent future billing errors.
appeal_checklist: Obtain and attach primary insurance EOB showing their payment or denial decision.
Include letter explaining coordination of benefits and confirming primary payer processed claim.
Verify BCBS has correct COB information on file before resubmitting claim.
Submit within BCBS appeal timeframe, typically 180 days from denial date.
risk_warnings: Patient may receive balance bill if primary insurance denies or pays less than expected.
Delayed submission to primary payer may result in timely filing denial from both insurers.
If COB information is incorrect in system, future claims will continue to deny.

results.description: Coding denial - procedure code inconsistent with modifier

data.plain_english_explanation: Humana denied this claim because the billing code for the knee injection (20610) was missing a required modifier. Since both knees were injected, the claim needed modifier 50 to indicate a bilateral procedure. Without it, the payer could not process payment correctly.
likely_root_causes: Modifier 50 (bilateral procedure) was not appended to CPT 20610 for both knee injections.
Billing system may not have prompted for bilateral modifier when two knees were documented.
Provider documentation confirmed bilateral service but coding did not reflect this.
Humana contract requires modifier 50 for bilateral joint injections to process payment.
missing_information_needed: Confirmation that both knees were injected during the same session on 2026-02-05.
Humana's specific modifier policy for CPT 20610 bilateral procedures.
Whether separate units or modifier 50 is preferred by this payer.
Copy of the original claim as submitted showing codes and modifiers used.
recommended_next_steps: Verify medical record documents bilateral knee injections performed on the same date.
Resubmit claim with CPT 20610-50 modifier attached to indicate bilateral procedure.
Check Humana provider manual for bilateral injection coding requirements and payment policy.
Contact Humana provider services to confirm correct modifier before resubmitting the corrected claim.
appeal_checklist: Medical record showing both knees injected with osteoarthritis diagnosis M17.0 documented.
Corrected claim form with CPT 20610-50 modifier properly appended.
Cover letter explaining the billing error and requesting claim reprocessing.
Reference to Humana policy allowing bilateral modifier 50 for joint injections if available.
risk_warnings: This is a contractual obligation denial; patient cannot be billed for this amount.
Resubmit promptly as timely filing limits may apply for corrected claims.
If modifier 50 is incorrect per Humana policy, payment may be denied again.

results.description: Medicare denial - should mention MAC/state variability

data.plain_english_explanation: Medicare denied this power wheelchair claim because the documentation did not prove it was medically necessary under their local coverage rules. Additionally, no Advance Beneficiary Notice (ABN) was signed before service, so the patient cannot be billed. The provider must absorb the cost unless the appeal succeeds.
likely_root_causes: Documentation did not meet Medicare's specific criteria for power wheelchair medical necessity under the Local Coverage Determination.
Missing or incomplete face-to-face evaluation notes showing why a manual wheelchair is insufficient for this patient's condition.
No Advance Beneficiary Notice was obtained before delivering the wheelchair to warn patient of potential denial.
Diagnosis codes M62.81 and Z74.09 may not strongly support power wheelchair necessity without additional clinical detail.
missing_information_needed: Copy of the applicable Medicare Local Coverage Determination for power wheelchairs to verify specific documentation requirements.
Complete face-to-face evaluation notes detailing mobility limitations and why manual wheelchair or walker is inadequate.
Clinical notes documenting patient's ability to safely operate power wheelchair and home environment assessment.
Confirmation whether prior authorization was attempted or required by the Medicare Administrative Contractor for this item.
recommended_next_steps: Request the specific Local Coverage Determination from your Medicare Administrative Contractor to identify exact documentation gaps.
Obtain detailed physician letter explaining why power wheelchair is medically necessary and manual options are insufficient.
Gather all face-to-face encounter notes, mobility assessments, and home environment evaluations to support medical necessity.
File appeal within 120 days with comprehensive clinical documentation addressing LCD criteria; verify deadline with MAC.
appeal_checklist: Physician letter of medical necessity specifically addressing Local Coverage Determination criteria for power wheelchairs.
Complete face-to-face evaluation notes documenting mobility limitations and why less costly alternatives are inadequate.
Clinical records showing diagnoses, functional limitations, home environment assessment, and safe operation ability.
Appeal filed within 120 days with all supporting documentation; confirm exact deadline and submission process with MAC.
risk_warnings: Provider cannot bill patient due to missing ABN and contractual obligation; financial loss unless appeal succeeds.
Medicare LCD requirements vary by region; verify your MAC's specific power wheelchair coverage criteria before resubmitting.
Future claims require ABN if medical necessity is questionable to protect against similar denials.

risk_warnings: Appeal deadlines may be running; act quickly to get clarification
Non-standard codes may indicate payer system error requiring escalation
Hospital may need to rebill with corrections once issue identified

results.description: Minimal input - just the required field with no useful info

data.plain_english_explanation: Your insurance denied this claim because they determined the service was not medically necessary. This is a contractual denial (CO-50), meaning the provider agreed not to bill you for this amount. The insurer believes the treatment wasn't required based on your condition or their coverage rules.
likely_root_causes: Clinical documentation did not demonstrate medical necessity for the service billed.
Service may not meet payer's specific medical policy criteria or coverage guidelines.
Diagnosis codes submitted may not support the procedure performed.
Prior authorization was not obtained when required by the payer's policy.
missing_information_needed: CPT or HCPCS procedure codes that were billed on this claim.
ICD-10 diagnosis codes submitted to justify the medical necessity.
Payer's specific medical policy for the denied service or procedure.
Place of service and claim type (professional, outpatient, inpatient, or DME).
recommended_next_steps: Request the payer's medical policy for the denied service to understand coverage criteria.
Review clinical documentation to confirm it supports medical necessity for the procedure.
Verify diagnosis codes accurately reflect the patient's condition and link to procedure.
Contact the provider's billing department to discuss appeal options and required documentation.
appeal_checklist: Obtain physician letter of medical necessity explaining why service was clinically required.
Gather clinical notes, test results, and prior treatment history supporting the claim.
Compare documentation against payer's medical policy criteria for the specific service.
Submit appeal within payer's deadline with all supporting clinical evidence attached.
risk_warnings: You should not be billed for this amount due to contractual obligation.
Appeal deadlines vary by payer; verify timeframe to avoid losing appeal rights.
Without clinical context and procedure codes, appeal strategy cannot be fully determined.
